data.text: What If My Bikepacking Trip Goes Wrong? Is there an AAA for Cycling?

I'm planning my first mini tour ( about 800 miles) and have been thinking about everything that could go wrong and how to remedy those situations. It got me thinking, is there such a thing as AAA for biking. What happens if your bike fails, you can't fix it and you're in the middle of a tour? Since I have no experience touring yet, I was wondering what can be done in this situation.

Sounds like fun! I wouldn't call 800 miles a mini tour though. I would definitely recommend an overnighter or two to figure things out. Where will you be traveling? Somewhere really remote? Or cars passing nearby frequently? Bike shops in nearby towns?
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: Here in BC, Canada the AAA equivalent, called BCAA, offers bike membership. If you’re on a road, they will either pick you up or fix your bike. However, since a lot of my riding is on trails, they won’t come & get you there. I carry a SPOT satellite beacon in case I need to be rescued, & also to keep in touch with friends & family. I’ve never had to use it, but a friend fell & hit her head a few years ago, & the search & rescue helicopter landed about 40 minutes after they sent the SPOT SOS.

data.text: It’s best not to plan a trek that has an absolute return by date. You can hit maintenance, weather, or amazement along the way and spend two or three days where you didn’t plan to. Best advice, for every three days of riding plan a rest day. For every two rest days plan a break day. Then plan at least two days on the back end before you have to be back for work or responsibilities. This way, if you break along the route you have plenty of time to make up. Or you can ditch your bike, bus home, grab a car, recover your bike, and plan for your next trek with a better idea of what could happen. And remember, when packing spares 2 is 1 and 1 is none.

data.text: Identify towns on your route that have bike shops before you depart. Have their phone numbers and addresses on you before departing. Know which one is closest at any time during your ride. Pack walkable footwear incase your walk to them is 20 miles and always always always bring spare parts (extra chain link, tubes, stans, lube, spokes, derailleur hanger at a minimum). I'm still waiting for the bike shop equivalent to weed maps to come out.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Do a series of long shakedown rides on an established route or bike path with plenty of service options nearby. This is what I did with my new build on the empire Trail system in New York before taking it to Alaska last summer. Get comfortable fixing everything you reasonably can but be prepared to have to ship your bike and/or yourself back by some other means if there's a catastrophic failure. The other option is to pay lots of money for a fully supported tour....
